clusters.title: Trump limits annual refugees to U.S. to 7,500. It’ll be mostly white South Africans
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Administration Sets Refugee Admission Cap

items.title: Trump limits annual refugees to U.S. to 7,500. It’ll be mostly white South Africans
items.standfirst: The Trump administration is restricting the number of refugees admitted annually to the United States to 7,500 and they'll be mostly white South Africans.
items.content: The Trump administration is restricting the number of refugees admitted annually to the United States to 7,500 and they'll be mostly white South Africans.

items.title: Trump caps refugee admissions at record low - with most to be white South Africans
items.standfirst: The president sets the limit at 7,500 for the coming year, a dramatic cut from 125,000.
items.content: The president sets the limit at 7,500 for the coming year, a dramatic cut from 125,000.

items.title: Trump administration sets lowest-ever cap on refugee admissions to U.S.
items.standfirst: The lowest cap on refugees since the program was established in 1980 comes as the U.S. prioritizes resettling Afrikaners from South Africa.
items.content: The lowest cap on refugees since the program was established in 1980 comes as the U.S. prioritizes resettling Afrikaners from South Africa.(Image credit: Farooq Naeem)

items.title: US will limit number of refugees to 7,500 and give priority to white South Africans
items.standfirst: Low number represents a dramatic drop after US previously allowed in hundreds of thousands of people fleeing war and persecutionThe Trump administration is going to restrict the number of refugees it admits into the United States next year to the token level of just 7,500 – and those spots will mostly be filled by white South Africans.The low number represents a dramatic drop after the US previously allowed in hundreds of thousands of people fleeing war and persecution from around the world. Continue reading...
items.content: Low number represents a dramatic drop after US previously allowed in hundreds of thousands of people fleeing war and persecutionThe Trump administration is going to restrict the number of refugees it admits into the United States next year to the token level of just 7,500 – and those spots will mostly be filled by white South Africans.The low number represents a dramatic drop after the US previously allowed in hundreds of thousands of people fleeing war and persecution from around the world. Continue reading...

US to limit number of refugees to 7,500 in 2026
items.standfirst: The administration of United States President Donald Trump will limit the number of refugees it admits annually into the country to 7,500 in fiscal year 2026, while prioritizing white South Africans. ...
items.content: The administration of United States President Donald Trump will limit the number of refugees it admits annually into the country to 7,500 in fiscal year 2026, while prioritizing white South Africans. ...

items.title: Historic Drop: U.S. Refugee Ceiling Falls To 7,500 Under Trump Order
items.standfirst: The Trump administration has capped the number of refugees entering the United States at 7,500 for the 2026 fiscal year, a sharp decline from the 125,000 limit set under former President Joe Biden. BREAKING:Trump sets an annual limit for refugee arrival at 7500. Preference will be given to white…
items.content: The Trump administration has capped the number of refugees entering the United States at 7,500 for the 2026 fiscal year, a sharp decline from the 125,000 limit set under former President Joe Biden. BREAKING:Trump sets an annual limit for refugee arrival at 7500. Preference will be given to white…

items.title: Trump sets lowest refugee cap in U.S. history at 7,500, mostly for Afrikaners
items.standfirst: The Trump administration on Thursday announced it would set the lowest refugee admissions cap in U.S. history at 7,500 spots.
items.content: The Trump administration on Thursday announced it would set the lowest refugee admissions cap in U.S. history at 7,500 spots.

ai_summary: The Trump administration will limit refugee admissions to 7,500 for the coming year.
This represents a significant decrease from the previous limit of 125,000.
The administration plans to prioritize white South African refugees.
The policy is a sharp decline from previous allowances for refugees.
The new cap is the lowest since the refugee program began in 1980.

items.title: Senate passes bill to nullify Trump’s sweeping global tariffs on more than 100 nations – US politics live
items.standfirst: Vote passes 51-47 in latest bipartisan effort to end tariffs, after resolutions on repealing Canada and Brazil tariffs passed earlier this weekUS government shutdown: tell us how it could affect your access to food or health insuranceIn the days leading up to the Trump-Xi meeting, American officials signalled that the US president did not intend to make good on a recent threat to impose an additional 100% import tax on Chinese goods.Also that China had shown signs it is willing to relax its export controls on rare earths as well as revive buying soybeans from the US.The relationship with China is very good.Because of the tremendous destructive power, I HATED to do it, but had no choice! Russia is second, and China is a distant third, but will be even within 5 years.Because of other countries testing programs, I have instructed the Department of War to start testing our Nuclear Weapons on an equal basis. That process will begin immediately. Continue reading...
items.content: Vote passes 51-47 in latest bipartisan effort to end tariffs, after resolutions on repealing Canada and Brazil tariffs passed earlier this weekUS government shutdown: tell us how it could affect your access to food or health insuranceIn the days leading up to the Trump-Xi meeting, American officials signalled that the US president did not intend to make good on a recent threat to impose an additional 100% import tax on Chinese goods.Also that China had shown signs it is willing to relax its export controls on rare earths as well as revive buying soybeans from the US.The relationship with China is very good.Because of the tremendous destructive power, I HATED to do it, but had no choice! Russia is second, and China is a distant third, but will be even within 5 years.Because of other countries testing programs, I have instructed the Department of War to start testing our Nuclear Weapons on an equal basis. That process will begin immediately. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump orders Pentagon to resume testing nuclear weapons "immediately"
items.standfirst: Minutes before meeting with China's President Xi Jinping, President Trump ordered the Pentagon to immediately resume testing nuclear weapons. CBS News national security contributor Sam Vinograd has more.
items.content: Minutes before meeting with China's President Xi Jinping, President Trump ordered the Pentagon to immediately resume testing nuclear weapons. CBS News national security contributor Sam Vinograd has more.

items.title: New York declares state of emergency to issue food banks $65m amid shutdown
items.standfirst: Oregon and Virginia also issued emergency declarations to fund food assistance as shutdown imperils Snap benefitsShare how government shutdown could affect your access to food or health insuranceUS politics live – latest updatesNew York’s governor, Kathy Hochul, on Thursday declared a state of emergency to free up funds so that she could issue $65m in assistance to food banks because federal funding for the national food stamp program is set to lapse on 1 November.Oregon and Virginia have also issued emergency declarations to release state cash to go towards emergency food assistance as the federal government shutdown imperils Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (Snap) benefits for nearly 42 million Americans. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump orders Pentagon to restart nuclear weapons testing after 33-year halt
items.standfirst: Just before meeting with China's Xi Jinping, President Trump announced he had directed the Pentagon to resume testing of nuclear weapons "on an equal basis" with other countries.
items.content: Just before meeting with China's Xi Jinping, President Trump announced he had directed the Pentagon to resume testing of nuclear weapons "on an equal basis" with other countries.

items.title: Donald Trump announces US to start nuclear weapons testing again
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump said he has ordered the Pentagon to start nuclear weapons testing to equal China and Russia, a significant change in the US's weapon strategy. The move comes after Russian President Vladimir Putin announced the successful test of a nuclear-capable, nuclear-powered underwater drone, in defiance of Washington's warnings.
items.content: US President Donald Trump said he has ordered the Pentagon to start nuclear weapons testing to equal China and Russia, a significant change in the US's weapon strategy. The move comes after Russian President Vladimir Putin announced the successful test of a nuclear-capable, nuclear-powered underwater drone, in defiance of Washington's warnings.

items.title: Trump directs nuclear weapons testing to resume for first time in over 30 years

items.content: It is necessary for the US to keep pace with weapons programmes in China and Russia, the president says.

items.title: Trump directs Pentagon to match Russia and China in nuclear weapons testing
items.standfirst: US president makes threat after Russian nuclear-powered weapons tests and shortly before meeting with Chinese leaderDonald Trump has instructed the Pentagon to immediately start matching other nuclear powers in their testing of nuclear weapons, specifically citing Russia and China.In a post to Truth Social, Trump said “because of other countries’ testing programs, I have instructed the Department of War to start testing our Nuclear Weapons on an equal basis. That process will begin immediately.” Continue reading...
items.content: US president makes threat after Russian nuclear-powered weapons tests and shortly before meeting with Chinese leaderDonald Trump has instructed the Pentagon to immediately start matching other nuclear powers in their testing of nuclear weapons, specifically citing Russia and China.In a post to Truth Social, Trump said “because of other countries’ testing programs, I have instructed the Department of War to start testing our Nuclear Weapons on an equal basis. That process will begin immediately.” Continue reading...

items.title: Trump says agreements with China include terms on soybeans and rare earth minerals
items.standfirst: President Trump said that his discussions with China's President Xi Jinping included topics like soybeans, rare earth minerals and TikTok. CBS News' Willie James Inman reports, and Kelly O'Grady has more on the potential economic impacts of the talks.
items.content: President Trump said that his discussions with China's President Xi Jinping included topics like soybeans, rare earth minerals and TikTok. CBS News' Willie James Inman reports, and Kelly O'Grady has more on the potential economic impacts of the talks.

items.title: Tariff cuts, soybeans, rare earths exports: Trade takeaways from Trump-Xi meeting
items.standfirst: From the lowering of US tariffs on Chinese goods to an agreement by Beijing not to tighten restrictions on rare earths exports, the meeting between President Donald Trump and China's Xi Jinping Thursday was a "great success", the US leader said. While China has not officially commented on the specifics of the agreements, here are some key takeaways of the talks, according to US officials.
items.content: From the lowering of US tariffs on Chinese goods to an agreement by Beijing not to tighten restrictions on rare earths exports, the meeting between President Donald Trump and China's Xi Jinping Thursday was a "great success", the US leader said. While China has not officially commented on the specifics of the agreements, here are some key takeaways of the talks, according to US officials.

items.title: Both US and China leaders get concessions to help domestic economy in deal
items.standfirst: U.S. President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping concluded their high-stakes meeting in South Korea with a trade-war truce. While there were no drastic changes in the relationship, the two sides did agree to a year-long extension of their current, temporary agreement. Both leaders got concessions that will help them domestically. But there are no signatures yet, leaving the door open for a change of mind.
items.content: U.S. President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping concluded their high-stakes meeting in South Korea with a trade-war truce. While there were no drastic changes in the relationship, the two sides did agree to a year-long extension of their current, temporary agreement. Both leaders got concessions that will help them domestically. But there are no signatures yet, leaving the door open for a change of mind.

items.title: Xi-Trump meeting: America has discovered that bullies can be bullied back
items.standfirst: Outcome appears closer to truce than durable peace but outline of broader diplomatic relationship is visibleFive key takeaways from Trump-Xi meetingWhen Donald Trump launched his trade war against China in April, threatening tariffs as high as 145%, the Chinese government said it would never bow to blackmail and vowed to “fight to the end”.The question now is whether the consensus reached between Trump and Xi Jinping in Busan, South Korea, on Thursday means that the fight really has come to an end, and if so on whose terms. Continue reading...
items.content: Outcome appears closer to truce than durable peace but outline of broader diplomatic relationship is visibleFive key takeaways from Trump-Xi meetingWhen Donald Trump launched his trade war against China in April, threatening tariffs as high as 145%, the Chinese government said it would never bow to blackmail and vowed to “fight to the end”.The question now is whether the consensus reached between Trump and Xi Jinping in Busan, South Korea, on Thursday means that the fight really has come to an end, and if so on whose terms. items.title: What Trump and Xi did and did not agree upon in their meeting
items.standfirst: From fentanyl to rare earths, President Donald Trump’s highly anticipated meeting with Chinese leader Xi Jinping saw the world’s two biggest economies ease their trade tensions, or at least some of them.
items.content: From fentanyl to rare earths, President Donald Trump’s highly anticipated meeting with Chinese leader Xi Jinping saw the world’s two biggest economies ease their trade tensions, or at least some of them.

items.title: Trump-Xi meeting: US president says rare earths deal and tariff cut agreed
items.standfirst: Donald Trump hails ‘amazing’ trade talks with Chinese counterpart, with ‘no roadblock at all on rare earth’Five key takeaways from Trump-Xi meetingAnalysis: price of confrontation was too high for both sidesDonald Trump has described crucial trade talks with the Chinese president in South Korea as “amazing”, saying their dispute over the supply of rare earths had been settled and that he would visit China in April.Xi Jinping has not commented on Thursday’s discussions but noted that the economic and trade teams from both countries had “reached a basic consensus on addressing our respective major concerns” during recent talks in Kuala Lumpur, according to Chinese state media. That had “provided the necessary conditions” for their meeting on Thursday, he added. Continue reading...
items.content: Donald Trump hails ‘amazing’ trade talks with Chinese counterpart, with ‘no roadblock at all on rare earth’Five key takeaways from Trump-Xi meetingAnalysis: price of confrontation was too high for both sidesDonald Trump has described crucial trade talks with the Chinese president in South Korea as “amazing”, saying their dispute over the supply of rare earths had been settled and that he would visit China in April.Xi Jinping has not commented on Thursday’s discussions but noted that the economic and trade teams from both countries had “reached a basic consensus on addressing our respective major concerns” during recent talks in Kuala Lumpur, according to Chinese state media. That had “provided the necessary conditions” for their meeting on Thursday, he added. Continue reading...

items.content: President Donald Trump and Chinese leader Xi Jinping will meet in Busan, South Korea, to discuss tariffs, fentanyl and rare-earth minerals.

clusters.title: Who is Rob Jetten, tipped to become the next Dutch prime minister?
clusters.neutral_headline: Rob Jetten Tipped to Become Next Dutch Prime Minister

items.title: Who is Rob Jetten, tipped to become the next Dutch prime minister?
items.standfirst: The race between anti-immigration Geert Wilders' far right Party for Freedom and the centrist D66 is still neck and neck. However given all major parties have ruled out forming a coalition Wilders, it is likely the energetic Rob Jetten of D66 will become the countries next prime minister - even if he comes second. So who is the 38-year-old and what is his agenda?
items.content: The race between anti-immigration Geert Wilders' far right Party for Freedom and the centrist D66 is still neck and neck. However given all major parties have ruled out forming a coalition Wilders, it is likely the energetic Rob Jetten of D66 will become the countries next prime minister - even if he comes second. So who is the 38-year-old and what is his agenda?

items.title: Tough coalition talks ahead as Dutch centre left and far right tie in election
items.standfirst: The centre-left party D66 and the far-right Party for Freedom are neck-and-neck in the Dutch snap election, but regardless of the winner there will have to be talks to build a coalition. Yet it is likely that the next prime minister will be D66 leader Rob Jentten rather than Geert Wilders, as parties have rejected collaborating with the latter again. FRANCE 24's Fernande Van Tets breaks it down for us from Amsterdam.
items.content: The centre-left party D66 and the far-right Party for Freedom are neck-and-neck in the Dutch snap election, but regardless of the winner there will have to be talks to build a coalition. Yet it is likely that the next prime minister will be D66 leader Rob Jentten rather than Geert Wilders, as parties have rejected collaborating with the latter again. FRANCE 24's Fernande Van Tets breaks it down for us from Amsterdam.

items.standfirst: ChatGPT developer is considering filing for an IPO by the second half of 2026, according to reportsOpenAI is reportedly gearing up for a stock market listing valuing the company at $1tn (£76bn) as soon as next year, in what would be one of the biggest ever initial public offerings.The developer behind the hit AI chatbot ChatGPT is considering whether to file for an IPO as soon as the second half of 2026, according to Reuters, which cited people familiar with the matter. items.title: Sudan’s El Fasher Turns Into A Kill Zone As RSF Massacres Civilians
items.standfirst: Hundreds of civilians were reportedly massacred in El Fasher, Sudan, after the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) seized the city. Verified videos show RSF fighters executing unarmed civilians, including patients inside the Saudi Hospital, where over 460 people were killed, according to the World Health…
items.content: Hundreds of civilians were reportedly massacred in El Fasher, Sudan, after the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) seized the city. Verified videos show RSF fighters executing unarmed civilians, including patients inside the Saudi Hospital, where over 460 people were killed, according to the World Health…

items.title: ‘They killed civilians in their beds’: chaos and brutality reign after fall of El Fasher
items.standfirst: Thousands have fled the Sudanese city in terror with stories of the Rapid Support Forces attacking and killing civiliansHundreds reportedly killed at Sudanese hospital as evidence of RSF atrocities mountsNawal Khalil had been volunteering as a nurse for three years at El Fasher South hospital when the Sudanese city was captured on Sunday by the Rapid Support Forces (RSF). She was busy treating patients, including an elderly woman who needed a blood transfusion, when the attack began.“They killed six wounded soldiers and civilians in their beds – some of them women,” she says. “I don’t know what happened to my other patients. I had to run when they stormed the hospital.” Continue reading...
items.content: Thousands have fled the Sudanese city in terror with stories of the Rapid Support Forces attacking and killing civiliansHundreds reportedly killed at Sudanese hospital as evidence of RSF atrocities mountsNawal Khalil had been volunteering as a nurse for three years at El Fasher South hospital when the Sudanese city was captured on Sunday by the Rapid Support Forces (RSF). She was busy treating patients, including an elderly woman who needed a blood transfusion, when the attack began.“They killed six wounded soldiers and civilians in their beds – some of them women,” she says. “I don’t know what happened to my other patients. I had to run when they stormed the hospital.” Continue reading...

items.title: Hundreds reportedly killed at Sudanese hospital as evidence of RSF atrocities mounts
items.standfirst: Rapid Support Forces, which claimed control of El Fasher on Sunday, reportedly killed at least 460 people ‘in cold blood’Sudan’s Rapid Support Forces killed hundreds of patients and staff inside a hospital in El Fasher, according to the World Health Organization and the Sudan Doctors Network, after the paramilitary group claimed control of the city on Sunday.The WHO secretary general, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, said he was “appalled and deeply shocked” at reports that more than 460 people had been killed at the Saudi maternity hospital, without assigning blame, in a post on X. Continue reading...
items.content: Rapid Support Forces, which claimed control of El Fasher on Sunday, reportedly killed at least 460 people ‘in cold blood’Sudan’s Rapid Support Forces killed hundreds of patients and staff inside a hospital in El Fasher, according to the World Health Organization and the Sudan Doctors Network, after the paramilitary group claimed control of the city on Sunday.The WHO secretary general, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, said he was “appalled and deeply shocked” at reports that more than 460 people had been killed at the Saudi maternity hospital, without assigning blame, in a post on X. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The Rapid Support Forces (RSF) reportedly massacred civilians in El Fasher, Sudan.
Verified videos show RSF fighters executing unarmed civilians.
The Saudi Hospital in El Fasher saw over 460 deaths.
Thousands fled El Fasher due to RSF attacks and killings.
A nurse witnessed RSF killing patients in their beds.

clusters.title: US Federal Reserve cuts interest rates for second time in a year
clusters.neutral_headline: US Federal Reserve cuts interest rates again

items.title: US Federal Reserve cuts interest rates for second time in a year
items.standfirst: The Federal Reserve lowered interest rates again on October 30 as it seeks to ensure economic growth and hiring, even as inflation stays elevated. It is the first time since the Fed’s rate-setting committee was established in the 1930s that officials have set monetary policy while lacking an entire month of crucial employment data, due to the government shutdown.
items.content: The Federal Reserve lowered interest rates again on October 30 as it seeks to ensure economic growth and hiring, even as inflation stays elevated. It is the first time since the Fed’s rate-setting committee was established in the 1930s that officials have set monetary policy while lacking an entire month of crucial employment data, due to the government shutdown.

items.title: Fed cuts interest rates for second time this year amid economic uncertainty
items.standfirst: Central bank sets rates at range between 3.75% and 4% amid turbulence from government shutdown and Trump’s tariffsThe US Federal Reserve cut interest rates on Wednesday, the second rate cut this year amid economic turbulence from the federal government shutdown and Donald Trump’s tariffs.The decision to cut the Fed’s benchmark interest rate by a quarter point to a range of 3.75% to 4% comes at an extraordinary moment for the central bank. The Fed has been under immense pressure from Donald Trump to cut rates despite persistent inflation and no longer has access to key data thanks to the shutdown. Continue reading...
items.content: Central bank sets rates at range between 3.75% and 4% amid turbulence from government shutdown and Trump’s tariffsThe US Federal Reserve cut interest rates on Wednesday, the second rate cut this year amid economic turbulence from the federal government shutdown and Donald Trump’s tariffs.The decision to cut the Fed’s benchmark interest rate by a quarter point to a range of 3.75% to 4% comes at an extraordinary moment for the central bank. The Fed has been under immense pressure from Donald Trump to cut rates despite persistent inflation and no longer has access to key data thanks to the shutdown. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The Federal Reserve lowered interest rates for the second time this year.
The rate cut aims to ensure economic growth and hiring.
The Fed's rate-setting committee lacks crucial employment data.
The government shutdown has impacted access to key economic data.
The Fed cut rates to a range between 3.75% and 4%.

clusters.title: Police raid in Brazil leaves more than 100 people dead
clusters.neutral_headline: Police raid in Brazil results in many deaths

items.title: Police raid in Brazil leaves more than 100 people dead
items.standfirst: Police raids in Brazil have killed more than 100 people, including four officers, making it the deadliest police operation in the nation's recent history. Rio de Janeiro Gov. Cláudio Castro says they seized weapons, drugs, and arrested roughly 80 alleged gang members. NBC News' Ellison Barber has more on the deadly operation.
items.content: Police raids in Brazil have killed more than 100 people, including four officers, making it the deadliest police operation in the nation's recent history. Rio de Janeiro Gov. Cláudio Castro says they seized weapons, drugs, and arrested roughly 80 alleged gang members. NBC News' Ellison Barber has more on the deadly operation.

clusters.title: Israel strikes Gaza again after overnight bombardment that killed at least 104
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel strikes Gaza after ceasefire breach

items.title: Israel strikes Gaza again after overnight bombardment that killed at least 104
items.standfirst: Attacks shatter Palestinians’ short-lived relief since start of ceasefire that now looks increasingly fragileIsrael carried out another strike in the Gaza Strip on Wednesday, killing at least two people, after bombarding the territory overnight and killing at least 104 Palestinians, including children, in the gravest challenge yet to the increasingly fragile US-brokered ceasefire. The Israeli military said it had struck military infrastructure where weapons were being stored for an imminent attack in Beit Lahia, northern Gaza. Al-Shifa hospital in Gaza City said it had received two bodies from the strike. Continue reading...
items.content: Attacks shatter Palestinians’ short-lived relief since start of ceasefire that now looks increasingly fragileIsrael carried out another strike in the Gaza Strip on Wednesday, killing at least two people, after bombarding the territory overnight and killing at least 104 Palestinians, including children, in the gravest challenge yet to the increasingly fragile US-brokered ceasefire. The Israeli military said it had struck military infrastructure where weapons were being stored for an imminent attack in Beit Lahia, northern Gaza. Al-Shifa hospital in Gaza City said it had received two bodies from the strike. Continue reading...

items.title: Israel says ceasefire back on after strikes kill more than 100 in Gaza
items.standfirst: Israel said Wednesday that the ceasefire in the Gaza Strip was back on after it carried out intense strikes across the Palestinian enclave that killed 100 people, including children, according to local health officials
items.content: Israel said Wednesday that the ceasefire in the Gaza Strip was back on after it carried out intense strikes across the Palestinian enclave that killed 100 people, including children, according to local health officials

items.title: Israel strikes Gaza after Netanyahu accuses Hamas of breaching ceasefire
items.standfirst: Prime minister accuses Hamas of ‘clear violation’ of truce as far-right ministers clamour to resume warIsraeli warplanes struck Gaza on Tuesday night, shortly after Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, ordered the military to carry out “powerful strikes” in Gaza, in the most serious test of the increasingly shaky US-brokered ceasefire.Witnesses reported seeing Israeli planes launch strikes on Gaza City, as well as explosions across the strip shortly after Netanyahu’s announcement. At least seven people were killed in separate strikes in Gaza City and Khan Younis, including two children, medical sources said. Continue reading...
items.content: Prime minister accuses Hamas of ‘clear violation’ of truce as far-right ministers clamour to resume warIsraeli warplanes struck Gaza on Tuesday night, shortly after Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, ordered the military to carry out “powerful strikes” in Gaza, in the most serious test of the increasingly shaky US-brokered ceasefire.Witnesses reported seeing Israeli planes launch strikes on Gaza City, as well as explosions across the strip shortly after Netanyahu’s announcement. At least seven people were killed in separate strikes in Gaza City and Khan Younis, including two children, medical sources said. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Israel struck Gaza after an overnight bombardment.
The overnight bombardment killed at least 104 Palestinians.
The ceasefire is increasingly fragile.
Israel said the ceasefire was back on after strikes.
Netanyahu accused Hamas of breaching the ceasefire.
